Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Ultra Low-Cost Mechanical Metamaterials to Enable Mobility and Interactivity for Cyber-Physical Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of origami-inspired mechanical metamaterials. These techniques can generate tessellated patterns that augment and enhance common materials. With the capacity for simultaneously making conventional materials lighter, stronger, and multi-functional, this material design motif has the potential to impact a wide range of technologies in hardware, manufacturing, energy-efficiency, robotics, and aerospace. This potential can be tapped by embedding carefully designed geometric patterns into materials. The current unmet challenge for realizing this potential impact is the conspicuous absence of a standard library of metamaterial designs. This project addresses the challenge by exploring the feasibility of a complete kinematic set and to determine whether the resulting physical properties are suitable for broader engineering applications. If successful, the metamaterials designed and validated by this effort will lay the foundation for replacing, augmenting, or enhancing machines of all types with mechanical metamaterial-based technology.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project utilizes an artificial intelligence-enhanced optimization scheme to automatically generate mechanical metamaterial designs meeting user-defined target properties. To generate the proposed set of kinematically-complete mechanical metamaterials the software-based approach to metamaterial design will be required to mesh with empirical validations. A combination of supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques will be used to guarantee the metamaterial designer routinely generates useful, robust, and high-performing schematics that qualitatively and quantitatively improve as the pipeline for metamaterial design is repeatedly executed. The core algorithm improves the ability to produce high-impact metamaterial-based technology while taking less time to converge on optimized design schematics. As such, the barrier to market penetration of advanced material technology becomes lower, faster, and is driven by advances in machine learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to translate academic research on advanced materials and manufacturing into commercial technologies.  Like honeycomb materials common to aerospace, our mechanical metamaterials use geometric patterning to create lightweight load-bearing structures.  We design these patterns to enhance or suppress deformation associated with buckling, bending, and other types of failure.  The technical outcome of this project is the development of a metamaterial geometry that's ~50x stronger than comparable lightweight composite structures but has negligable added material or manufacturing costs.  We further manufactured prototypes and demonstrated the anticipated improvements with standard mechanical tests.

Commercially, we discovered the technical advances supported by this effort are of high value in the transportation sector, where lightweight load bearing panels are used in the construction of semi-trailers sidewalls and electric vehicle battery boxes.  The mechanical metamaterial structures developed in this project are 80% lighter than the current industry standard and highly cost-competitive.  Semi-trailer manufacturers that integrate our materials into their construction benefit by achieving lighter and more durable design.  Semi-trailer owners and operators benefit from our materials by increasing their bottom-line profitiability through fuel savings and increased cargo hauling capacity (up to $1Mn/y in increased revenues and savings).

Future technical and commercial efforts will build on these results to advance a next-generation lightweight load bearing sandwich panel that exceeds aerospace-grade capabilities, but remains priced for non-aerospace markets.

Multiscale Systems is an advanced materials manufacturing firm commercializing applications of mechanical metamaterial technology for heavy industry.  Our ability to generate lighter, stronger, and more resiliant materials by patterning complex geometric patterns into conventional materials creates substantial value for engineered products without making chemical or molecular maniuplations.  The award directedly and indirectly supported five full-time jobs for a HUBZone firm in the advanced manufacturing sector.  Visit us at multiscalesystems.com to learn more.


Last Modified: 11/02/2020
Modified by: Jesse Silverberg
